titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Office of the Vice President, Media Projects, Office Files of Andrea L. Taylor
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Office of the Vice President, Media Projects, Office Files of Andrea L. Taylor FA684

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-03-13 15:15:19 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Office of the Vice President, Media Projects, Office Files of Andrea L. Taylor

physdesc.extent: 60 document containers and one half document container

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

When requesting to view audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916). Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact a RAC archivist for further instruction.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in seven series:
2. Subject Files on the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe, and Brazil, 1986-1990
3. Innovations in State and Local Government, 1986-1992
4. Changing Relations Project, America Becoming Documentary, 1983-1991

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Rockefeller Archive Center received ten accessions containing Andrea Taylor's files from the Ford Foundation between 2012 and 2021: Accessions 2018:018, 2012:084, 2019:018, 2019:027, 2019:048, 2019:077, 2019:093, 2019:067, 2019:109, and 2021:086.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence with grantees, press releases, background materials on media grantmaking institutions, memos, drafts of Ford publications, trip files, subject files, meeting invitations, articles, grant proposals, invitations to film screenings and festivals, conference files, and other materials created and received by Andrea Taylor in her roles as media officer and founder and director of Media Projects at the Ford Foundation.

The files within the collection pertain to documentaries, public radio, public broadcasting, media grantmakers and media organizations, media and public policy, social justice and civil rights, the Innovations in State and Local Government awards program, the work of community foundations, museums, and media portrayal of HIV/AIDS.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains conference materials, grant information, and news releases related to the 1989 Leadership Program for Community Foundations organized by the Ford Foundation and MacArthur Foundations. The series also contains background information on various community foundations.

Subject Files on Soviet Union, Eastern Europe, and Brazil

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains subject files on the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe, and Brazil used to plan, prepare for, and carry out work-related trips. In 1989, Taylor was a member of the Council on Foundations' delegation of twenty-five foundation executives and trustees who were invited to visit the Soviet Union. She traveled to Brazil in 1989 to review Ford Foundation media projects.

Innovations in State and Local Government

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 1986, the Ford Foundation, with the assistance of the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, initiated an awards program on Innovations in State and Local Government. The objective of the program was to demonstrate that government is capable of responding creatively and effectively to critical social issues. Each winning program received a Foundation grant of $100,00 to disseminate information about the program and encourage its replication. From 1986 until 1995 (with a hiatus in 1989), the awards honored ten states, cities, counties, and tribal or public authorities for exemplary innovative programs. In 1995, the Foundation expanded the number of $100,000 awards from ten to 15 and began honoring federal Innovations as well.

The Foundation undertook a variety of outreach activities in support of the Innovations Program. It hired a public relations firm to disseminate information about award-winners, finalists, and semi-finalists, and to promote awareness of the program in the popular media and trade press. It also sponsored a program booklet to publicize Innovations programs that was mailed members of Congress and other government officials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains press releases, marketing materials, planning meeting files, Innovating America by Fred Jordan book materials, Innovating America film materials, ceremony planning correspondence and invitations, press coverage analysis, articles, and background on award winners.

Changing Relations Project, America Becoming Documentary

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 1987, in response to increasing immigration in the 1980s, the Ford Foundation provided a grant to the State University of New York to study the relationships and everyday interactions among recent immigrants and longer-term residents. The Changing Relations project employed ethnographic research methods in Chicago, Houston, Miami, Philadelphia, Monterey Park, California, and Garden City, Kansas. A National Board directed the project by defining its scope, organizing its research, and awarding subgrants to local research teams.

In addition to a final report published in 1993, the project produced a 9O-minute documentary called America Becoming, which was filmed on location at the research sites and aired on public television in 1991. The documentary was directed by Charles Burnett co-written by Charles Burnett and Dai Sil Kim-Gibson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists of files related to the 1991 documentary, America Becoming, created as part of the Ford Foundation's Changing Relations project. The series contains correspondence with writer Dai Sil Kim-Gibson, meeting materials, conference papers, news releases, project notes, reports, grant documents, and marketing documents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains correspondence with grantees and prospective grantees, invitations to seminars and conferences, articles and reports sent to Andrea Taylor, Ford Foundation press releases, promotional mail, invitations to film screenings, meeting materials, and trip files. The files pertain to documentaries, film projects, film festivals, updates from media grantmakers, public radio programs, public broadcasting, public policy initiatives, Black media, race relations, diversity initiatives, media portrayal of HIV/AIDS, women in media, Native American films, and issues in journalism.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Council on Foundations is a nonprofit membership association founded in 1949 to provide tools and leadership opportunities for philanthropic organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists of correspondence, meeting notes, conference materials, reports, and articles created by various groups within the Council on Foundations, including the Technology Task Force, Grantmakers in Film, TV, and Video, and the Education Committee.
